intro: Pseudodissochaeta, commonly known as the common sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of Africa and the Middle East. It belongs to the family Amaranthaceae and is characterized by its prostrate growth habit and hairy stems. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically green or reddish in color. Its leaves are narrow and often covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss in harsh environments. Pseudodissochaeta is adapted to thrive in sandy soils and can often be found in disturbed or open habitats.
